2. Check Platformer 3d demo

Use `Material demo` and eventually `Platformer 3D` demo

data.title: Replacement of internal RegEx with PCRE2
data.body:
Turns out PCRE2 was not as heavy as I thought and was fairly easy to integrate into Godot. This is the minimal feature-parity-ish commit. Plans to introduce serialised compilations and JIT speed-ups would come separately later.

~~**That said, discussion is needed for `modules/regex/SCsub`.** Due to how `wchar_t` can be 32 bit on *nix but 16-bit on Windows, it is necessary to know at compile-time its width. Unfortunately, I'm not sure the tests in `modules/regex/SCsub` is the right place (or even the right method).~~

~~If someone more familiar with SCons can help me out, that'd be great.~~

## Notable minor breaking changes:

* The pattern and replacement matching behaviour has been changed purely due to the nature of switching to a standards-compliant library.
* One mistake in the previous behaviour was that named groups didn't have a number. This has been corrected.
* As names are actually just an alias of numbered groups, `RegExMatch::get_name_dict()` has been removed. Also, for clarity, `RegExMatch::get_group_array()` has been renamed.
* Due the lack of a suitable equivalent in PCRE2, `RegExMatch::expand()` was removed.

data.title: Inherited Models don't hold information about textures/mappings
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Linux, e12b422c90f3f866d133ea5ab797fb37f675e019

**Issue description:**
After creating inherited scene for dae model, it's impossible to setup mapping and textures, because the information will be lost after closing the scene:
![inheritedmaterial](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6129594/29033022-e8ba3624-7b93-11e7-8a9c-b7b3f1af71c7.gif)

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Download reproduction project.
2. Open stone.tscn
3. Setup albedo texture
4. Save and close
5. Open stone.tscn again

**Link to minimal example project:**
[Inherited Material Issue.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1205262/Inherited.Material.Issue.zip)

data.title: Edit an exported scene var from the inspector's dropdown menu
data.body:
If you export a variable to get another scene reference in current one. You get a nice line in the inspector representing the scene. But if you want to edit it, you are to open it manually, though it is right there. It would be a nice feature if user could be able to open/edit the scene from the dropdown menu in the inspector. Fro now you can only 'Edit' the resource properties of the scene, which is not quiet what is expected.

Is applicable for both 2.x and 3.x branches.

data.title: Dropdown button with 'three dots' in the UI is unusable
data.body:
The dropdown button in the UI is unusable to it's tiny width. To open a dropdown menu you need to 'put a thread through a needles hole'.
The arrows in version 2.0 were just about right size, I never experienced any issues with them, why do the have to be replaced?

data.title: [Suggestion] Extra options for child node/object to "Inherit" transform or global transform from the parent node/object?
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 3.0 Alpha

I'm not certain of this is an interesting idea to implement in Godot or not but when sometimes I parent a child object to the main object (Whether its is a 2D or 3D Spatial Node) it forces the child to rotate and move with the parent. However, an idea made me think: If a node becomes a child to a parent, should there be an extra option that shows up at the bottom or within the transform submenu of the Inspector Panel that shows a checkmark(boolean) if you want the child to inherit the Translation, Rotation, and Scale of the Parent?

Say I want to make one part of the child node not rotate with the parent, I could easily uncheck the "Inherit Parent Rotation" to make it rotate in its own local/global transform rather than imitating the parent rotation.

Or leave the child scale small while the parent grows big by unchecking the "Inherit Parent Scale" to the child node.

Just a simple idea for Godot that could open up more simpler creative ways to modify nodes/objects.

data.title: Allow documentation of exported script properties
data.body: Often script properties are supposed to be edited by artists (or, in general, not by the author of the script) and a tooltip explaining their meaning would be helpful. But it seems currently Godot only supports tooltips for builtin properties documented in `classes.xml`. It should be easy to expand `PropertyInfo` with documentation field which could be settable from GDScript or other bindings.

data.title: Add handling of touch events in _gui_input_event
data.body:
Fixes #10039 

Since there is no visible progress on the issue, I thought, maybe PR will fasten the discussion a bit.

This is the solution I propose to fix problems I pointed out in the issue.
Logic of handling touch events is pretty much the same as for mouse event:
1. Find a control under touch position or `mouse_focus` if it's not null.
2. Check for modal controls - if topmost modal control is unrelated to control under cursor, do nothing.
3. If control can process event, transform everything to control-local coordinates, then pass event to `_gui_call_input`
4. Call `set_input_as_handled`

data.title: Support of custom render sort order in 3D
data.body:
Currently Godot 3.0 supports render sorting based on various characteristics of materials, but sometimes games need to sort objects within same material group using a custom value. In our game specifically, ground meshes beneath buildings have alpha, and special effects (particles and meshes, always above ground level) also have alpha. The engine is not able to decide in which order to render them without additional information, which we cannot provide to it at the moment, so it renders them in arbitrary order.

A related problem is that for some reason [Godot assumes](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/d9a97aae04b947517c286f019ce7cd8abd3745fe/drivers/gles3/rasterizer_scene_gles3.cpp#L2185) that all Unshaded materials have alpha, which is actually rarely the case. This prevents from properly sorting materials that actually have or don't have alpha.

data.title: Fixed crash on exist, change to only use audio driver manager to finaize drivers
Adjust FileSystem dock split mode's height threshold
data.body:
This makes the FileSystem dock's "split mode" activate at a smaller height (`window_height / 2` rather than `window_height * 3/4`.) This allows other docks to be positioned in the same column at a more reasonable size, without FileSystem reverting back to the single-view mode.

Old: http://i.imgur.com/4Mh2xQc.png (if the Import dock were any taller the thumbnail view would [disappear](http://i.imgur.com/4WHVKXN.png))
New: http://i.imgur.com/Ahk2KQf.png

data.title: gltf importer doesn't support hinting through node names
data.body: Collada importer supports various useful hinting conventions for the importer as documented [here](http://docs.godotengine.org/en/stable/learning/features/3d/importing_3d_scenes.html), things like -colonly, -loop, etc. which are currently ignored by the gltf importer.

data.title: [3.0] Console flooded with blank spaces when using Interpolated Camera
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Ubuntu 17.04 -- Godot Alpha built 5th August.

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
Set up an interpolated camera, ran the scene and the Output was flooded with blank spaces. Every time the scene is opened up from now on the Ouput is flooded with blank spaces. 

**Steps to reproduce:**
Changed the following Interpolated Camera settings:

* Under **Interpolated Camera** 
  * I ticked enable
  * Assigned it to a target
* Under Camera I checked **current**

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->
[test_ipo.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1203482/test_ipo.zip)

data.title: Gridmap editor doesn't respects cell scale
data.body:
Godot 2.1.4 beta2
Windows 10 64 bits

Repro steps:
1) Create a MeshLibrary with a cube inside
2) Create a GridMap using the MeshLibrary, place a few cubes: they are placed normally
3) Set Cell size to 1 and scale to 0.5: notice the cubes you placed already are wrongly positionned and don't appear scaled
5) Set Cell size to 2, then back to 1: notice cubes you placed already get correctly positionned and scaled. However, the edition cursor still shows a preview at original scale. Reloading the scene doesn't fix it.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1311555/29006786-e967d786-7af6-11e7-915e-f4bd78a99add.png)

Project: 
[Gridmap3.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1203410/Gridmap3.zip)

data.title: Duplicate error messages to macOS logging system (Console.app)
data.body:
Non-bundled executables have annoying focus problems (#8907), and bundled app have `stdout` and `stderr` redirected to `/dev/null`.

This PR adds error message duplication to `Console.app` to save output from bundled app.

data.title: Fixed crash on exist, change to only use audio driver manager to finalize drivers
Add missing NULL checks to prevent possible crashes on _add_geometry
data.body: Closes #10064

data.title: Added a SIGSEGV handler that dumps the stacktrace to ease reporting
data.body:
This PR adds a simple crash reporter that dumps the stacktrace to stderr, implemented for various OSes:

- On Linux it adds a signal for SIGSEGV/SIGFPE that prints the stacktrace when the signal is triggered. It uses addr2line to get file/line number.

- On OS X it also adds a signal for SIGSEGV/SIGFPE that prints the stacktrace when the signal is triggered. It uses atos to get file/line number.

- On Windows it uses __try/__except to catch exceptions. Only supported on MSVC (no mingw support yet).

Note, the code is only enabled with crash_report=yes on debug mode, also after the stacktrace is generated the crash is passed to the OS so that you can debug if necessary.

This is a screenshot of how it shows the stacktrace on Linux:
![screenshot from 2017-08-06 17-18-12](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10578225/29006848-30865dfa-7ace-11e7-9586-e4aaf547f1ca.png)

On Windows:
![crashreport](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10578225/29011895-37c4df9e-7b0d-11e7-81e7-b2d5f44960dd.png)

On OS X:
![screen shot 2017-08-07 at 1 36 55 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10578225/29036789-43807bd0-7b77-11e7-8a5f-4bb83e50d306.png)

data.title: Fix is_class check typo in ObjectDB::cleanup
'Shift' in the Input Map for actions does not work for HTML5 exported projects
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 64 bit - 2.1.3.stable.

**NOTE: The example project below does NOT exhibit the bug. See my second comment below for an updated project + a slightly different description of the issue.**

**Issue description:**
The expected behavior is for `Input.is_key_pressed(KEY_SHIFT)` to return true when the Shift key is pressed in the browser. The actual behavior is that `Input.is_key_pressed(KEY_SHIFT)` always returns false.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Download the minimal example project.
2. Run the project inside the editor and press Shift. Notice that the Sprite disappears when Shift is pressed.
3. Export the project to HTML5, run the HTML5 exported project, and press Shift. Notice that the Sprite does **not** disappear.

**Link to minimal example project:**
[shift-test.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1202940/shift-test.zip)
